questions.text: A gym owner observes that individuals who drink iced tea during their workouts tend to lose more weight. What is the nature of this relationship?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Indirect

Type of Association

Description

Spurious (Option A)

An association that appears to be present but is actually due to chance or an error in data.

If the gym owner's observation was spurious, it would mean that the association between iced tea consumption and weight loss is completely false and exists due to some error in observation or data collection.

Indirect (Option D)

An association in which a third variable (known as the confounding variable) causes both the predictor and the outcome.

Direct (Causal)  (Option C)

An association where the predictor directly influences the outcome.

 

If the relationship between iced tea consumption and weight loss were direct, it would mean that drinking iced tea itself leads to weight loss. However, it is unlikely that drinking iced tea alone would have a direct effect on weight loss.

a. One-to-One causal

A direct causal link between a single predictor and a single outcome.

b. Multifactorial

An association involving multiple factors contributing to the outcome.

questions.text: What renal function is represented by the formula UV/P?
questions.explanation:
Inulin Clearance
  • Used to measure Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) as it is freely filtered but not reabsorbed or secreted.
  • Not ideal for routine use due to intravenous administration.

Creatinine Clearance
  • Estimates GFR using creatinine, which is primarily filtered by the glomeruli.
  • Slightly inaccurate due to tubular secretion, but practical for clinical settings.

PAH Clearance
  • Estimates Renal Plasma Flow (RPF).
  • PAH is cleared through both glomerular filtration and tubular secretion.
  • Correction for PAH extraction ratio improves accuracy.

questions.text: Identify the fracture shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Definition
  • A fracture of the radial head, the upper part of the radius that articulates with the humerus and ulna at the elbow joint.

Causes
  • Most commonly caused by a fall onto an outstretched hand (FOOSH)
  • Direct trauma or a blow to the elbow
  • MVA (Motor Vehicle Accidents) or sports injuries

Types of Fractures
  • Type I: Non-displaced fracture (usually treated conservatively)
  • Type II: Displaced fracture with a single fragment (may require surgical intervention)
  • Type III: Comminuted (multiple fragments, often requiring surgical reconstruction or replacement)

Symptoms
  • Pain and tenderness at the lateral aspect of the elbow
  • Swelling and bruising around the elbow joint
  • Limited range of motion, with flexion and extension
  • Difficulty supination and pronation

Diagnosis
  • Tenderness, swelling, and limited motion.
  • X-rays: Used to classify the type and displacement of the fracture.
  • CT scan: Used for more complex fractures.

Treatment Options
  • Conservative management: For non-displaced (Type I) fractures.
  • Surgical management: For displaced (Type II) or comminuted (Type III) fractures- radial head fixation, replacement (arthroplasty), or excision.

Complications
  • Loss of elbow range of motion
  • Chronic pain
  • Elbow instability
  • Post-traumatic arthritis
  • Stiffness or deformity of the joint

questions.text: Identify the fracture?
questions.explanation:
Definition
  • A fracture involving the lateral condyle of the humerus. It is typically seen in children.

Causes
  • Most commonly by direct trauma to the elbow (Fall on the outstretched hand or a direct blow).
  • Torsional forces during activity or sports.

Types of Fractures
  • Type I: Non-displaced fractures (usually treated conservatively).
  • Type II: Displaced fractures (may require surgical intervention).
  • Type III: Comminuted fractures with significant displacement (often require surgery).

Symptoms
  • Pain and swelling around the lateral aspect of the elbow.
  • Limited range of motion, especially during extension and rotation.
  • Deformity or abnormal positioning of the elbow joint (in more severe cases).
  • Tenderness over the lateral condyle.

Diagnosis
  • Clinical examination: History of trauma, swelling, and deformity.
  • X-rays: To assess fracture type and displacement. Lateral and AP views are commonly taken.
  • CT scan: Can help evaluate complex fractures or assess joint involvement.

Treatment Options
  • Non-displaced fractures (Type I): Conservative management with rest, ice, and a sling or cast for immobilization.
  • Displaced fractures (Type II): Require surgical fixation, such as the use of pins or screws.
  • Comminuted fractures (Type III): Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF).

Complications
  • Elbow stiffness or loss of range of motion.
  • Malunion or improper healing, leading to angular deformity.
  • Post-traumatic arthritis due to joint surface involvement.
  • Nerve injury (Radial nerve) due to fracture or surgical intervention.

questions.text: Relative bradycardia is seen in
questions.explanation:
Morphology

Biochemical Properties

Growth & Susceptibility

Small, non-motile, aerobic, Gram-negative coccobacilli

Catalase positive

Do not grow well on standard laboratory media

Non-capsulated and non-spore forming

Oxidase positive (except B. neotomae and B. ovis)

Destroyed by heat at 60°C in 10 minutes

Often exhibit a bipolar staining appearance

Urease positive

Killed by 1% phenol in 15 minutes
 

Utilize oxygen but do not typically ferment carbohydrates

Killed by pasteurization

Test

Description

Key Points

Standard Agglutination Test (SAT)

Tube agglutination test using serial dilutions of patient's serum and killed B. abortus antigen
  • Significant titer: 160 or more.
  • Acute brucellosis titer: 640 or more within 3-4 weeks.
  • Prozone phenomenon common.
  • False positives with cholera, tularemia, yersinia infection, or immunization

Complement Fixation Test

Detects IgG antibodies
  • Valuable in chronic cases

ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay)

Distinguishes between IgM and IgG antibodies
  • Useful for differentiating acute from chronic infections

Rapid Tests

Includes rapid dipstick tests and Rose Bengal card test
  • Quick results.
  • Can be used for initial screening

Characteristic

Details

Morphology

Small, non-motile, aerobic, Gram-negative coccobacilli, Non-capsulated, non-spore forming, Bipolar staining

Biochemical Properties

Catalase positive, Oxidase positive (except B. neotomae and B. ovis), Urease positive, Utilize oxygen, do not ferment carbohydrates

Growth & Susceptibility

Do not grow well on standard media. Destroyed by heat at 60°C in 10 min, Killed by 1% phenol in 15 min, Killed by pasteurization.

Zoonotic Nature

Affects goats, sheep, cattle, buffaloes, pigs. Human infection through contact or consumption.

Symptoms

Intermittent fever, loss of appetite, nausea, muscular and articular pains, fatigue, sweating, relative bradycardia, joint pain.

Blood Culture

Trypticase soy broth or brucella broth. Biphasic blood culture (Castaneda method). Large blood volume (5 ml). Incubation: 37°C, 5-10% CO2, 6-8 weeks. 30-50% positive cases. Bone marrow cultureshave a higher yield.

Serological Tests

SAT: Significant titer 160+, Acute 640+, Complement Fixation: IgG detection, ELISA: Distinguishes IgM & IgG. Rapid Tests: Dipstick, Rose Bengal

Antibiotics

Adults: Doxycycline 45 days, Streptomycin 2 weeks, Children: Cotrimoxazole + Rifampicin/Gentamycin.

Vaccination

No human vaccine, Occupational risk: Attenuated live vaccine, Animals: B. abortus strain 19 vaccine.

questions.text: Zellweger syndrome is associated with which cellular organelle?
questions.explanation:
Zellweger Spectrum Disorder

  • Rare autosomal recessive disorder with defective peroxisome biogenesis affecting VLCFA metabolism.
  • Includes Zellweger syndrome, neonatal adrenoleukodystrophy, infantile Refsum disease, and rhizomelic chondrodysplasia punctata.

Etiology
  • Caused by mutations in PEX genes encoding peroxins, primarily PEX1/PEX6
  • Functional peroxisomal disturbances:
    1. Zellweger spectrum: Generalized peroxisomal dysfunction.
    2. Adrenoleukodystrophy: Mutations in ABCD1, impacting VLCFA transport.
    3. Rhizomelic chondrodysplasia punctata: Multiple enzymatic defects.

Pathophysiology
  • Peroxisomes: Membrane-bound organelles with >50 enzymes for fatty acid metabolism, abundant in liver/kidney.
  • Mutated PEX genes disrupt peroxisome formation, leading to VLCFA accumulation, reduced steroid biosynthesis, and neuronal damage.
  • Major abnormalities:
    • Brain: Demyelination, neuronal injury.
    • Liver: Fibrosis.
    • Kidney: Cortical cysts.

Clinical Features

Multisystem involvement with severity depending on age of onset:

  • Neonatal-Infantile: Hypotonia, feeding issues, seizures, facial dysmorphism, ocular and hearing abnormalities, hepatomegaly.
  • Childhood: Developmental delay, FTT, hepatic dysfunction, adrenal insufficiency, neuroregression.
  • Adolescent-Adult: Neuroregression, ataxia, neuropathy, adrenal insufficiency, leukodystrophy.

Diagnosis
  • Initial: Clinical features + elevated VLCFA on newborn screening.
  • Biochemical tests: Elevated VLCFA, bile acid intermediates, and phytanic/pristanic acid; reduced plasmalogens.
  • Genetic testing: Confirms PEX mutations.
  • Prenatal diagnosis and genetic counseling recommended.

Management
  • No cure; supportive care focuses on improving quality of life.

 

Therapies:

  1. Docosahexaenoic acid
  2. Lorenzo oil: Reduces VLCFA but doesn't halt disease progression.
  3. Cholic acid: Approved for hepatic dysfunction.

 

Supportive Measures:

  • Hearing aids for hearing loss.
  • Ophthalmologic care for vision issues.
  • Antiepileptics for seizures.
  • Vitamin supplementation: Fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K).
  • Cortisone for adrenal insufficiency.
  • Gastrostomy for feeding difficulties.

questions.text: Which of the following microorganisms is likely responsible for causing bilateral infiltrates in an HIV-positive patient?
questions.explanation:
Pneumocystis jirovecii

Morphology
  1. Trophozoite - thin-walled, irregularly shaped, 1-5 µm in size
  2. Precyst - an intermediate stage of the sexual phase, 5-8 µm in size
  3. Cyst - thick-walled, spherical, containing up to 8 intracystic bodies and up to 8 µm in size

Risk factors
  • HIV: CD4 < 200
  • Primary immunodeficiency states
  • Transplant recipients
  • Hematological malignancies

Clinical features

Transmitted by respiratory droplets and is asymptomatic in immunocompetent individuals. In immunocompromised patients, life-threatening pneumonia develops.

PCP - Pneumocystis Carinii pneumonia

  • Dyspnoea
  • Dry cough
  • Fever
  • Weight loss
  • B/L interstitial pneumonia causing bilateral infiltrates

Diagnosis
  • GMS / Giemsa stain- mc used
  • Giemsa, toluidine blue, methenamine silver, and calcofluor white stains can demonstrate trophozoites - cyst wall is black with a methenamine silver stain.

 

 

Crushed Ping Pong ball (also called Helmet/Hat or Cup and Saucer appearance).

  • The β-d-glucan test has proven to be quite useful for rapid diagnosis of Pneumocystis pneumonia with a high degree of sensitivity and specificity.

Treatment
  • The cornerstone for both prevention and treatment is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.
  • Alternative therapies have been used in AIDS patients; they include pentamidine, trimethoprim-dapsone, clindamycin-primaquine, atovaquone, and trimetrexate.

questions.text: A couple brings their 4-year-old child to the outpatient department (OPD) due to self-mutilating behavior and poor growth. Which of the following associated enzyme deficiencies could explain these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome

Clinical Features

 
  • Metabolic: Severe gout, sodium urate crystal deposition causing joint swelling and kidney damage.
  • Neurological:
    • Poor muscle control.
    • Involuntary movements (resembling Huntington's disease).
    • Facial grimacing, repetitive limb movements.
  • Behavioral: Self-mutilation (lip and finger biting, starting ~2nd year).
  • Other: Moderate developmental delays, potential megaloblastic anemia (from poor vitamin B12 utilization).

Management
  • Metabolic: Allopurinol for gout; lithotripsy for kidney stones.
  • Neurological: Symptomatic treatment with drugs like carbidopa/levodopa, diazepam, phenobarbital, or haloperidol.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby presents with severe hepatomegaly, cataracts in both eyes, lethargy, and hypotonia. Based on these symptoms, which enzyme deficiency is most likely involved?
questions.explanation:
Galactosemia

Enzyme Deficiency
  • Galactose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase (GALT) - Classical type
  • Galactokinase- benign disease with only oil drop cataract. (Option A ruled out)
  • Epimerase- SNHL + symptoms of classical type

(Low galactose-based diet can be given which is contraindicated in the classical type)

Pathophysiology
  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate (toxic causing jaundice, and liver damage)
  • Inability to metabolize galactose from milk
  • Damage to liver, kidney, and brain

Clinical Features
  • Hepatic: Jaundice, hepatomegaly
  • GI: Vomiting, diarrhea, failure to thrive
  • CNS: Seizures, intellectual disability
  • Eyes: Oil drop cataracts
  • Increased risk of E. coli sepsis

Diagnosis
  • Reducing substance in urine (positive)( Positive Benedict test but negative glucose oxidase test)
  • Direct enzyme (GALT) assay
  • Genetic testing (Perinatal diagnosis is possible)

Management
  • Lactose-free diet
  • Breast Milk contraindicated
  • Soy-based or elemental formulas
  • Calcium supplementation

questions.text: What is the process of converting unconjugated substances into conjugated forms called?
questions.explanation:
Synthetic Reaction

Description

Examples

Glucuronidation

Conjugation with glucuronic acid via UDP-glucuronosyl transferases (UGTs).

Chloramphenicol, aspirin, paracetamol, morphine, bilirubin, steroid hormones, thyroxine.

Acetylation

Conjugation with acetyl CoA, mediated by N-acetyl transferases.

Isoniazid, sulfonamides, hydralazine, dapsone, clonazepam.

Methylation

Methylation of amines and phenols by methyl transferases using methionine or cysteine as donors.

Adrenaline, histamine, methyldopa, captopril, mercaptopurine.

Sulfation

Conjugation of phenols and steroids with sulfate by sulfotransferases (SULTs).

Chloramphenicol, methyldopa, adrenal steroids.

Glycine Conjugation

Conjugation with glycine for drugs with carboxylic acid groups.

Salicylates, nicotinic acid.

Glutathione Conjugation

Conjugation of reactive intermediates with glutathione via glutathione-S-transferases.

Paracetamol (reactive intermediates), quinones, epoxides.

Ribonucleoside Synthesis

Conjugation for activation of purine and pyrimidine antimetabolites.

Cancer chemotherapeutic agents.

questions.text: A patient with a history of strenuous exercise forgot to eat a meal and later consumed alcohol at a party. Which of the following metabolic processes is inhibited by alcohol consumption?
What is the preferred management for a pediatric patient with symptomatic adenoid hypertrophy causing chronic nasal obstruction and sleep apnea?
questions.explanation:
Management of Adenoid Hypertrophy:

Medical Management: (For Mild Cases initially)
  • Breathing exercises
  • Decongestant nasal drops
  • Antihistamines for any nasal allergies
  • Topical Nasal Steroids may reduce adenoid size and improve related symptoms.

Surgical Intervention: (Adenoidectomy)
  • Traditional Methods: Blind curettage adenoidectomy remains common, but it has disadvantages, including unpredictable bleeding and poor access to the choanal adenoid. Hence, Endoscopic management is currently preferred.
  • Direct Vision Techniques:
    • Suction Diathermy
    • Endoscopic Coblation/Microdebridement involves using endoscopy to visualise and allows for precise removal of obstructive adenoid tissue, addressing the underlying issue directly.
    • KTP Laser: Associated with a higher risk of nasopharyngeal stenosis, while the gold laser has not shown this risk.

questions.text: What is the most commonly used test for newborn hearing screening?

A 40-year-old female working as a senior executive leading a sedentary lifestyle presents to the OPD with palmoplantar pigmentation. X-ray spine shows calcification of intervertebral discs. On adding Benedict’s reagent to the urine sample, it gives a greenish-brown precipitate and comes positive. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Alkaptonuria

Definition

Rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of homogentisate 1,2 dioxygenase (HGD), an enzyme in the tyrosine metabolism pathway.

Mechanism and Pathophysiology

Defective tyrosine metabolism → homogentisic acid (HGA) accumulation → ochronotic pigment deposition → systemic disease (ochronosis).

 

  • Deficiency: HGD fails to convert HGA to maleylacetoacetate.
  • Consequences:
    • HGA oxidizes into melanin-like polymers → connective tissue deposition (ochronosis).
    • Affects joints, heart valves, kidneys, and vessels.

Clinical Features
  • Triad: Homogentisic aciduria, ochronosis, ochronotic osteoarthropathy.
  • Pediatric signs: Dark urine (oxidized HGA).
  • Musculoskeletal: Arthritis (spine, hips, knees), kyphoscoliosis, spinal stenosis.
  • Cardiac: Aortic stenosis, mitral valve disease, coronary artery disease.
  • Renal/Metabolic: Stones (renal, gallbladder, prostate).
  • Neurological: Peripheral neuropathy, stroke.

Evaluation
  • Clinical scoring: AKU Severity Score Index (AKUSSI).
  • Diagnostic tests:
    • Gold standard: Urinary HGA quantification via gas chromatography-mass spectrometry.
    • Genetic testing for HGD mutations.
    • Imaging (CT/MRI): Joint involvement, valvular calcification.
    • Echocardiography: Valvular abnormalities.

Management
  • Symptomatic: Pain control, physiotherapy, joint surgery.
  • Diet: Low-protein diet (limited efficacy).
  • Medications:
    • Vitamin C: Reduces HGA oxidation but not urinary excretion.
    • Nitisinone: Inhibits tyrosine metabolism, reduces HGA >95%. Side effects: tyrosinemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia.

Prognosis and Complications
  • Prognosis: Normal life expectancy; reduced quality of life (pain, sleep issues, disability).
  • Complications:
    • Stones (renal, gallbladder, salivary).
    • Tendon/ligament ruptures.
    • Osteopenia, fractures.
    • Aortic calcification/stenosis.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is characterized by the presence of a cherry red spot on the retina?
questions.explanation:
Tay-Sachs Disease

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Cause

Deficiency of hexosaminidase A enzyme

Accumulation

GM2 ganglioside in ganglion cells and neurons

Clinical Manifestations
  • Initial symptoms include loss of head control, inability to sit, exaggerated startle response to sound, and a disproportionately large head.
  • Progressive features include spasticity, deafness, and blindness.
  • Not associated with organomegaly.

Fundus Finding

Cherry-red spot is caused by GM2 ganglioside accumulation in the ganglion cells of the retina, creating a contrast with the normal red fovea.

questions.text: Identify the most common location of Nasopharyngeal carcinoma:
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Definition

• A deep recess located in the nasopharynx, behind the torus tubarius (the cartilaginous opening of the Eustachian tube)

Location

• Posterolateral wall of the nasopharynx

• Just behind the Eustachian tube opening

Clinical Importance

• Common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) origin

• Close to the pharyngeal opening of the Eustachian tube, so tumors here may cause ear symptoms

Related Structures

• Close to the Eustachian tube, tensor and levator veli palatini muscles, and retropharyngeal lymph nodes

Symptoms if Involved

• Unilateral ear blockage or hearing loss (due to Eustachian tube obstruction)

• Nasal obstruction, epistaxis (nosebleeds)

• Neck mass (from lymph node spread)

A farmer presents with a painful snakebite wound on his right foot. There are two fang marks with swelling and bleeding at the bite site. What is the first step in management?

options.text: Sling or splint leading to immobilization

options.label: D
options.text: See the snake brought by a relative

questions.correct_answer: B. Sling or splint leading to immobilization
questions.explanation:
Management

Details

Indications/Notes

First Aid
  • Do not allow the victim to walk (Carry)
  • Avoid tourniquets, except in specific cases(No)
  • Reassure patient
  • Immobilize bitten limb (Option B)
  • Transport to the hospital quickly
  • Tell the doctor about any systemic symptoms

Tourniquets only for severe elapid/sea snake bites with >0.5h but <2-3h transport time

Evaluation
  • Check for signs of envenomation
  • Monitor vital signs
  • Perform 20-minute whole blood clotting time
  • Check coagulation profile, CPK, renal function

Incoagulable blood indicates systemic envenomation by Viperidae

Antivenom Therapy
  • Mild: 50 ml
  • Moderate: 50-100 ml
  • Severe: 150-200 ml

Effective against the 4 most important venomous snakes in India, namely, Cobra, Common Krait, Russell's viper and saw-scaled viper.

Indications:

  • Haemostatic abnormalities
  • Neurotoxicity
  • Cardiovascular dysfunction
  • Impaired consciousness
  • Rhabdomyolysis
  • Extensive local swelling

Antivenom Administration (Option A)
  • Dilute in 5 ml/kg body weight of isotonic saline/5% Dextrose
  • Infuse over 1-2 hours
  • Monitor for hypersensitivity reactions

Repeat if severe signs persist after 1-2 hours or if coagulability is not restored within 6 hours

Supportive Care
  • Tetanus prophylaxis
  • Antibiotics (if severe local reaction)
  • Manage respiratory paralysis
  • Fresh frozen plasma/cryoprecipitates for severe bleeding

Avoid heparin, corticosteroids, and EDTA.

questions.text: Blood during autopsy is preserved in?
questions.explanation:
Specimen

Importance

Blood

Primary specimen; collect from femoral, iliac, or axillary veins to avoid contamination.

Preservative: Lithium heparin or EDTA tube, Sodium fluoride/oxalate (Option A), if alcohol is suspected

Urine

Useful for detecting parent compounds and metabolites of poisons.

Preservative: No preservative, sodium fluoride is added, if alcohol is

Suspected

Gastric Contents

Helps identify ingested poisons and their concentrations through vomitus and stomach contents analysis.

Preservative: Saturated salt solution if there is no chance of acid poison.(Option B)

Rectified spirit if poisoned by acid (Option C)

.

Liver

Analyzes metabolism and concentration of drugs; critical when blood/urine concentrations are low. Bile can detect specific substances like chlorpromazine and morphine.

Preservative: Saturated salt solution if there is no chance of acid poison.

Rectified spirit if poisoned by acid.

Hair and Nails

Detects heavy metal poisoning; metals accumulate in keratin. Neutron activation analysis identifies specific metals and exposure patterns.

Scene Residues

Provides clues about the poison through materials found at the scene, such as tablets or empty containers.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate treatment for a patient presenting with diarrhea and a flask-shaped ulcer on a colonoscopy?
questions.explanation:
Tissue Amebicidal Drugs

 

Metronidazole

 
  1. DOC for all forms of amebiasis
  2. Treats amebic colitis and liver abscess
  3. Penetrates well into body tissues and fluids, including vaginal secretions, seminal fluid, saliva, breast milk, and cerebrospinal fluid.
  1. Effective against Entamoeba histolytica trophozoites but less effective against cysts.
  2. Inhibits protein synthesis in Entamoeba
  3. Treats giardiasis, trichomoniasis, and anaerobic infections
  4. Used in combination therapy for H. pylori infection

Tinidazole

 

Amebic colitis and liver abscess

Also used to treat Trichomoniasis.

Ornidazole

Acute amoebic dysentery

 

Secnidazole

Emetine

Acute amoebic dysentery or amoebic liver abscess in patients not tolerating metronidazole
  • Directly acting amoebicide that kills trophozoites but has no effect on cysts.
  • Side effects include vomiting and cardiotoxicity.

Chloroquine

Amoebic liver abscess

Kills the liver stage of Entamoeba histolytica

Luminal Amebicidal Drugs

Drug

Uses

Additional points & S/E

Paromomycin

(DOC)

An Aminoglycoside

Luminal agent for amebiasis.

An alternative drug for Giardiasis, especially in the first trimester of pregnancy where metronidazole is C/I.

Diloxanide furoate

Mild intestinal amebiasis

Furoate is the active moiety that kills Entamoeba

Quiniodochlor

 

Rarely used due to dangerous side effects such as SMON (Subacute myelo-optico-neuropathy)

Iodoquinol

Contains iodine and can cause thyroid abnormalities and allergy

Luminal Amebicidal Drugs

Tissue Amebicidal Drugs
  • Paromomycin
  • Diloxanide furoate
  • Quiniodochlor
  • Iodoquinol
  • Metronidazole or its congeners (Tinidazole, Ornidazole)
  • Emetine
  • Chloroquine

Site of Action

Pancreatic β cells

Uses

Mechanism of Action

Sulfonylureas ⟶ Bind to Receptors on Pancreatic β Cells ⟶ Closure of ATP-sensitive K+ Channels ⟶ Membrane depolarization ⟶ Opening of Voltage-Gated Ca².+ Channels ⟶ Ca²+ Influx ⟶ Exocytosis of Insulin Granules ⟶ Increased Insulin Secretion ⟶ Lower Blood Glucose Levels.

Drugs

1st Generation

  • Tolbutamide
  • Chlorpropamide

2nd Generation

Teduglutide

Type

Peptide hormone (GLP-2 analogue )

Mechanism of Action

Teduglutide ⟶ Binds to GLP-2 Receptors on Intestinal epithelial cells ⟶ Activation of Guanylate Cyclase ⟶ Increased production of cGMP ⟶ Activation of Protein Kinase G⟶ Regulation of Tight Junctions and Epithelial transporters ⟶ Enhanced intestinal absorption of fluid and nutrients ⟶ Improved glycemic control.

Uses

Treatment of short bowel syndrome (SBS) in adult patients who are dependent on parenteral support.

Benefits
  • Reduces dependence on parenteral nutrition
  • Improves intestinal absorption and transit time
  • Increases nutrient absorption and fluid balance

  • Upper respiratory tract infection

  • Gastrointestinal cancer

Special Points

  • Dosing and adjustment should be based on individual patient responses.
  • Regular monitoring of nutritional status and fluid balance is essential.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures has been banned by the Supreme Court of India due to its association with sexual assault cases involving doctors?

Step

Details

Request for Examination
  • Any police officer can request it within 24 hours.

Consent
  • Must obtain consent from the woman
  • Examination supervised by a female RMP.

Initial Examination
  • Ask the victim to remove clothing.
  • Examine and collect evidence from clothes.

Detection of Micro Injuries
  • Apply toluidine-blue contrast to the anogenital area.

Swabs Collection
  • 4 swabs:

    • Sperm: Use saline for motility testing.
    • DNA Profiling
    • Chemical Tests: Acid phosphatase, creatinine phosphokinase, lactate dehydrogenase.

Examination Position
  • Examine in lithotomy position under good lighting.

Hymen Examination
  • Use Glaister-Keene rods or hymenoscope
  • Look for tears (usually posterior at 5-7 o'clock position).

Vaginal Examination
  • Use a speculum for vaginal examination.(Option C)

Cervical Examination
  • Use a colposcope for cervical examination. (Option B)

Post-Examination Care
  • Treat STDs, injuries, or potential pregnancy.
  • Provide psychological support.

questions.explanation:
Duration of Disease

Specimen Examination

% Positivity

1st week

90%

Faeces culture

80-100%

25-40%

Typhoid

Causative Agent

Salmonella enterica serotypes Typhi and Paratyphi A, B, and C

Transmission

Fecal-oral route via contaminated food/water, known as the "4 Fs" (flies, fingers, feces, and fomites)

Incubation Period

6-30 days (typically 10-14 days)

Key Symptoms
  • Gradually increasing fever (38-40°C)
  • Fatigue and malaise

  • Abdominal pain
  • Anorexia

Diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following is the diagnostic test for carcinoid tumors?
questions.explanation:
Diagnostic Method

Details

5-HIAA Urine Test
  • Primary diagnostic test
  • 24-hour urine collection
  • Measures serotonin metabolites
  • Can be challenging if patient is consuming serotonin-rich foods (e.g., salmon, eggs)

Somatostatin Scintigraphy
  • Also known as OctreoScan
  • Can confirm presence of somatostatin receptors
  • Helps in tumor localization
  • Used to predict response to somatostatin analogue therapy

68Ga-DOTATATE PET Scan
  • More sensitive imaging technique
  • Uses radioactive gallium-68
  • Helps predict response to treatment
  • Particularly useful for NET imaging

Chromogranin A
  • Blood test biomarker
  • Elevated in metastatic disease
  • Should be interpreted with caution in patients with renal dysfunction, patients taking PPIs
  • Not diagnostic alone, but helpful in monitoring

Clinical Symptoms
  • Flushing episodes (2-5 mins)
  • Diarrhea
  • Wheezing
  • Heart valve problems
  • Abdominal pain
  • Telangiectasia

Carcinoid syndrome
  • Carcinoid syndrome is caused by hormone secretion (mainly serotonin) from neuroendocrine tumors (NETs).
  • Commonly arises from NETs in the small intestine or appendix.
  • The syndrome typically occurs when the tumor has metastasized to the liver or retroperitoneum, allowing the hormones to enter systemic circulation.
  • Histamine and tachykinins (e.g., substance P) may also contribute to the syndrome.

Common Symptoms
  • Flushing: Sudden onset of an intense red or purplish color, especially on the upper body, neck, and face, often with a sensation of warmth.
  • Diarrhea: Frequent watery stools, often over 10 times/day, significantly impacting daily life.

Less Common Symptoms
  • Wheezing or asthma-like symptoms
  • Impaired cognitive function in advanced cases
  • Pellagra-like skin lesions due to niacin deficiency (from tryptophan being used to produce serotonin instead of niacin).

Management
  • Somatostatin analogues: Mainstay treatment that mimics somatostatin, which inhibits hormone secretion (e.g., serotonin).
    • Most NETs (around 90%) have somatostatin receptors and respond to these analogues.
  • Telotristat ethyl: Blocks serotonin production; used as adjunctive therapy for patients who don't fully respond to somatostatin analogues.
  • Surgery: Considered for localized tumors but often not possible in patients with metastatic disease.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a 20-year history of chronic alcohol consumption, averaging 500 ml daily, presents to the clinic with complaints of sensations of insects crawling on his skin, agitation, and irritation. He reports that his last drink was 3 days ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Stage of Alcohol Withdrawal

Symptoms

Onset After Last Drink

Treatment

Mild Withdrawal

Mild anxiety, tremulousness, nausea, headache, palpitations

6-8 hours

Benzodiazepines (lorazepam, chlordiazepoxide, diazepam). Carbamazepine (800 mg daily).

Moderate (Alcoholic Hallucinosis)

Visual, auditory, or tactile hallucinations, intact orientation, normal vital signs

8-12 hours

Benzodiazepines (lorazepam, chlordiazepoxide, diazepam).

Severe (Withdrawal Seizures)

Generalized tonic-clonic seizures, usually brief and self-limited (rum fits)

12-24 hours

Benzodiazepines (Treatment of choice).

Anticonvulsants not more beneficial.

Life-Threatening (Delirium Tremens)

Severe agitation, confusion, disorientation, visual hallucinations, autonomic hyperactivity, profound sweating, tremors, insomnia

Within 72 hours

Higher doses of Benzodiazepines (50-100 mg chlordiazepoxide every 4 hours or lorazepam IV). Supportive care (high-calorie diet, multivitamins).

Haloperidol for severe agitation (caution with seizure threshold).

Protracted Withdrawal

Symptoms may last 2-6 months

-

Acamprosate is recommended for symptom relief, and cognitive and behavioural approaches are recommended.

questions.text: A mother presented her daughter with complaints that she has started behaving weirdly about her food habits for the last few months. She eats a lot of burgers in one go, and then she vomits it out. Her BMI is 27. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Bulimia Nervosa (eating disorder)

Age of Onset

Late adolescence and young adulthood (8-21 years).

Features

  • Binge Eating Episodes: Recurring episodes of binge eating, occurring at least weekly for the last 3 months.
  • Compensatory Behaviors: Purging behaviours (self-induced vomiting, laxative abuse, diuretics), excessive exercise, fasting.
  • BMI: Often normal or slightly overweight (compared to anorexia nervosa).
  • Gender prevalence: More common in females than males.

Physical signs

Appear due to repeated purging.

  • Parotitis or (parotid gland hypertrophy (may see increased serum amylase)
  • Enamel erosion (from vomiting)
  • Dental caries
  • Mallory-Weiss syndrome (esophageal tears).
  • Russell's Sign (callus on knuckles: Due to self-induced vomiting, the knuckles get injured by the teeth.

Treatment

Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT):

  • First-line treatment focuses on modifying distorted thoughts and behaviours related to eating and body image.

Nutritional Rehabilitation:

  • Aimed at restoring healthy eating patterns and addressing nutritional deficiencies.

Antidepressants

  • Fluoxetine: Most effective medication for reducing binge-eating episodes and associated symptoms.
  • Topiramate: This can be effective in suppressing binge eating but not as commonly used as fluoxetine.
  • Bupropion: Contraindicated due to an increased risk of seizures, especially in patients with eating disorders.

Evidence indicates that CBT and medications (particularly fluoxetine) are the most effective combination.

questions.text: A young woman presents with recurrent headaches, easy bruising, and episodes of visual blurring. Her platelet count is elevated, while her red blood cell (RBC) and white blood cell (WBC) counts are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Essential Thrombocytosis

Definition
  • Clonal myeloproliferative disorder
  • Characterized by increased platelet production
  • Abnormal megakaryocyte proliferation

Genetics
  • JAK2 V617F mutation (50-60% of cases)
  • CALR mutations (type 1 and 2)
  • MPL mutations

Lab Findings
  • Platelet count >450,000/μL
  • Increased bone marrow megakaryocytes
  • Normal RBC and WBC Count

Clinical Features
  • Often asymptomatic
  • Thrombotic events (arterial > venous)
  • Erythromelalgia
  • Ocular migraines & visual disturbances
  • TIAs
  • Spontaneous bleeding & easy bruising

Diagnostic Criteria
  • Platelet count >450,000/μL
  • Bone marrow showing megakaryocyte proliferation
  • Not meeting WHO criteria for other myeloid neoplasms
  • Presence of JAK2, CALR, or MPL mutation

Complications
  • Thrombosis (major cause of morbidity)
  • Hemorrhage (especially with counts >1 million/μL)
  • Progression to myelofibrosis
  • Small risk of leukemic transformation

Treatment
  • Low-dose aspirin for thrombosis prevention
  • Hydroxyurea for high-risk patients
  • Anagrelide for cytoreduction
  • Plateletpheresis for severe cases

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient who has been on anti-diabetic therapy for the last 10 years, has experienced three episodes of vaginal candidiasis infections in the past two months. Which hypoglycemic agent should be avoided in this patient?
A 30-year-old woman presents with a unilateral throbbing headache that worsens with exposure to bright light. She occasionally skips breakfast. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features of Migraine

Premonitory (Prodromal) Phase
  • Neck discomfort
  • Cognitive impairment (brain “fog”)
  • Mood changes
  • Fatigue
  • Yawning/sleepiness
  • Increased urination and thirst
  • Food cravings

Aura
  • Neurologic disturbances (e.g., visual disturbances like scintillating scotoma)
  • Due to Cerebral vasoconstriction. Therefore prevention is by Vasodilators.

Headache Phase
  • Pain
  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Sensory sensitivities:
    • Photophobia (sensitivity to light)
    • Phonophobia (sensitivity to sound)
    • Osmophobia (sensitivity to smells)
    • Allodynia (pain from non-painful stimuli)
    • Vertigo
  • Due to cerebral vasodilation. So treatment is Vasoconstrictors

Postdrome
  • Tiredness
  • Weariness
  • Impaired concentration

Simplified Diagnostic Criteria for Migraine by International Headache Society:

Criteria:

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4–72h in patients with a normal physical examination, no other reasonable cause for the headache, and:

 

At least 2 of the following features:

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

 

Plus at least 1 of the following features:

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text: Which nerve defect causes lagophthalmos?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Most common cause of facial palsy
  • Characterized by idiopathic, LMN facial paralysis of acute onset
  • Most commonly the Labyrinthine segment of the facial nerve is involved.
  • Males and females are equally affected.

Aetiology
  • Idiopathic: Most common cause
  • Viral Infection: HSV >> Herpes zoster
  • Vascular Ischemia
  • Hereditary: Positive family history in 6-8%
  • Autoimmune

Risk Factors
  • More common in diabetics (due to angiopathy) and pregnant women (due to fluid retention).

Clinical Features
  • Sudden onset of facial paralysis with inability to close the eye (Bell's phenomenon) (Option A), asymmetry of the face, epiphora, drooping mouth, and dribbling of saliva.
  • Associated symptoms may include ear pain, noise intolerance (stapedial paralysis), or loss of taste (chorda tympani involvement).

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis is made by excluding other causes of peripheral facial paralysis.

Treatment
  • General: Reassurance, pain relief, eye protection and physiotherapy
  • Medical: Prednisolone 60 mg per day for 5 days then reduced by 10 mg per day (for a total treatment time of 10 days) and 50 mg per day (in two divided doses) for 10 days, Acyclovir
  • Surgical: Nerve decompression

Prognosis
  • 85%-90% of patients fully recover
  • Incomplete resolution are mainly seen in recurrent/late recovery cases

NPCB Classification of Visual Impairment

The National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) in India defines blindness as "visual acuity of <3/60 in a better eye with best possible correction" and central visual field <10 degrees. The NPCB further categorizes visual impairment as:

Classification

Visual Acuity

Visual Impairment

Visual acuity of less than 6/18 in the better eye with available correction

Low Vision

Visual acuity of less than 6/18 to 6/60

Economic Blindness

Visual acuity of less than 6/60 to 3/60

Social Blindness

Visual acuity of less than 3/60 to 1/60

Manifest Blindness

Visual acuity of less than 1/60 to the perception of light

Absolute Blindness

No perception of light

WHO Classification of Visual Impairment

The World Health Organization (WHO) defines blindness as "visual acuity of less than 3/60 (Snellen) or its equivalent".(Option A)

The International Classification of Disease 11 (2018) classifies vision impairment into distance and near-presenting vision impairment

Classification

Visual Acuity

Mild Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/12

Moderate Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/18

Severe Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/60

Blindness

Presenting visual acuity worse than 3/60

Near Vision Impairment

Presenting near vision acuity worse than N6 or M0.8 at 40 cm with existing correction

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest marker to rise in a case of myocardial infarction (MI)?
questions.correct_answer: D. Heart fatty acid binding protein
questions.explanation:
Cardiac Markers

Cardiac Troponin

(Troponin T and I) (Option B ruled out)
  • Preferred biochemical markers due to their sensitivity and specificity.
  • Troponin levels:
    • Increase within 3-6 hours.
    • Peak at around 36 hours.
    • Remains elevated for 7-10 days after STEMI.
  • Troponin should be measured at presentation and repeated at 1-3 hours (high-sensitivity assays) or 3-6 hours (conventional assays).
  • Cardiac troponin levels remain elevated for several days after an acute myocardial infarction (AMI), making them unreliable for detecting reinfarction.

Creatine Phosphokinase (CK) and CK-MB

(Option A ruled out)
  • CK rises within 4-8 hours.
  • Peaks by 24 hours.
  • Returns to normal within 48-72 hours.
  • CK-MB elevated:
    • Cardiac surgery
    • Myocarditis
    • Electrical cardioversion
  • CK-MB levels normalise within 48 to 72 hours, so a subsequent rise can confirm reinfarction.

Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH) (Option C ruled out)
  • Increase in the blood 6 to 12 hours after ACS.
  • Peak within 24 to 72 hours.
  • Normalise within 8 to 14 days.
  • LDH is no longer used to diagnose myocardial infarction because it is not specific to cardiac myocytes.

Heart-type Fatty Acid-Binding Protein (H-FABP)

(Option D)
  • It is the earliest marker to rise in a case of myocardial infarction (MI).
  • It has higher sensitivity than troponin and CK-MB for detecting AMI within 4 hours of symptom onset, but its specificity is lower.

Cardiac Enzyme

Time to rise

H-FABP(Heart fatty acid binding protein)

Within 1 hour

Troponin T and I

2-4 hrs

CK-MB

2-4 hrs

LDH1

24 hrs

questions.correct_answer: A. Schedule for laparoscopic mesh repair
questions.explanation:
Technique

Mesh Placement

Procedure

Advantages

Disadvantages

Inlay

Within the fascial defect itself

Mesh is sutured to the edges of the fascial defect.

It can be used for large defects where primary closure isn't possible.

High recurrence rates due to mesh separation from fascial edges under abdominal pressure

Onlay

On top of the anterior rectus sheath/external oblique aponeurosis

Subcutaneous tissue is dissected off; the fascial defect is closed primarily, and the mesh is placed on top and secured

Technically easier and less invasive.

Higher risk of seroma formation, mesh infection, and skin necrosis.

Retromuscular

 

Behind the rectus muscle but anterior to the posterior rectus sheath

The posterior rectus sheath is opened, the mesh is placed in the created space, and the posterior sheath is closed over it

Lower recurrence rates, mesh well incorporated into tissues

More complex procedure, risk of injury to neurovascular bundles.

Preperitoneal

 

Between the peritoneum and the posterior rectus sheath.

Peritoneum is separated from posterior rectus sheath, mesh is placed in this space, peritoneum is closed over it.

Good mesh incorporation, lower risk of adhesions.

Technically challenging, risk of peritoneal tears.

questions.text: A neonate is diagnosed with gastroschisis. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Omphalocele

Gastroschisis

Definition

Congenital abdominal wall defect where abdominal contents protrude through the base of the umbilicus.

Congenital abdominal wall defect is when abdominal contents protrude through a defect typically located to the right of the umbilicus.

Covering

The herniated organs are covered by two layers: Amnion (outer) and peritoneum (inner).

No membrane covers the exposed organs.

Associated conditions
  • Chromosomal abnormalities: Associated with Trisomy 13, 18, and 21.
  • Other congenital malformations affect multiple systems in the following order: cardiovascular> Muscular> gastrointestinal> genitourinary. (Mnemonic: "CM GIGU")
  • Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome: Can include hemihypertrophy, macroglossia, visceromegaly, omphalocele, and increased risk of hepatoblastoma.
  • Fewer chromosomal abnormalities compared to omphalocele.
  • Higher risk of intestinal atresia and dysfunction.

Prognosis

Generally poor due to associated congenital malformations, which are the most common cause of death.

Generally better than omphalocele due to fewer associated congenital anomalies.

Management
  • Primary surgical closure is preferred for small to medium-sized defects.
  • Larger defects may require:
  • Prosthetic patch closure (e.g., Gore-Tex),
  • Porcine small intestinal submucosa-derived biomaterials (e.g., Surgisis),
  • Skin flap closure, or
  • Placement of a silo for sequential reduction and staged closure.
  • For giant omphaloceles, topical application of escharotic agents like povidone-iodine (Betadine) ointment or silver nitrate is used to thicken and epithelialize the sac.
  • Primary closure is typically done under general anesthesia and often requires admission to the NICU for postoperative ventilation.
  • Alternatively, a preformed silo can be placed at the bedside for gradual reduction, sometimes avoiding the need for general anesthesia altogether.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is pneumomediastinum commonly found?
questions.explanation:
Boerhaave syndrome

Definition

It is a spontaneous esophageal rupture caused by a sudden increase in intraesophageal pressure, typically from vomiting against a closed glottis resulting in a left-sided esophageal perforation, which allows gastric contents to spill into the pleural cavity, leading to a left pleural effusion and subcutaneous emphysema.

Classic triad

Vomiting, chest pain, and subcutaneous emphysema. (Mackler’s triad)

Other Symptoms

May include fever, tachycardia, and tachypnea in the presence of sepsis

Physical examination

Hamman’s sign (crunching sound on auscultation due to surgical emphysema).

Complications

Pneumothorax/Pneumomediastinum, mediastinitis, and sepsis.

questions.text: Which of the following organs is a primary lymphoid organ?
questions.explanation:
Primary Lymphoid Organs

Secondary Lymphoid Organs

Bone Marrow:

  • Origin of all blood cells from pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells (a process called hematopoiesis).
  • Hematopoiesis shifts to bone marrow from the liver after fetal life, eventually confined to axial bones after puberty.
  • Progenitor T and B cells develop in bone marrow; B cells mature here, while T cell progenitors migrate to the thymus.

Lymph Nodes: (Option A ruled out)

  • Filter antigens and activate T and B cells.
  • Structured into cortex (B cell area), paracortex (T cell area), and medulla (rich in plasma cells).

Spleen: (Option B ruled out)

  • Largest secondary lymphoid organ, involved in filtering blood-borne antigens.
  • Contains white pulp (T and B cells) and red pulp (site of RBC destruction).

Thymus: (Option C)

  • Site of T cell proliferation and maturation.
  • Developed from the third/fourth pharyngeal pouch in embryonic life.
  • Active during childhood, decreases in size after puberty.
  • Thymic hormones (e.g., thymulin, thymopoietin) help attract and mature T cells.
  • Central tolerance occurs here, removing self-reactive T cells to prevent autoimmunity.

Mucosa-associated Lymphoid Tissue (MALT): (Option D ruled out)

  • Located in mucosal sites (intestine, respiratory, urogenital tracts) to protect against pathogens.
  • Includes loose clusters of lymphoid cells and organised structures (e.g., tonsils, Peyer’s patches in intestines).

questions.text: A 30-year-old man experiences initial paralysis in both legs, which then progresses to affect both upper limbs as well. Over time, he shows slight improvement in upper limbs but no improvement in his lower trunk and both legs. Based on this description, what is the most likely diagnosis?
A patient develops a severe infection and necrosis in the scrotal region after 5 days of catheterization. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Fournier's Gangrene

Definition
  • Necrotizing infection of the soft tissues in the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region, akin to necrotizing fasciitis.

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms: Intense pain in the genitalia, progressing through

five phases:

    • Prodromal Phase: Fever and lethargy.
    • Early Pain Phase: Intense pain, possible edema, pruritus.
    • Progressive Phase: Increased pain, and erythema.
    • Crepitation Phase: Dusky skin with subcutaneous crepitation.
    • Gangrene Phase: Gangrene with purulent discharge.
  • Pain may decrease as gangrene progresses.
  • Severity ranges from localized tenderness to septic shock.

Risk Factors
  • Peripheral vascular disease, diabetes mellitus, malnutrition, alcoholism, immunocompromised states.

Diagnosis
  • Clinical presentation supported by imaging or lab findings.

Management
  • Initial Treatment:
    • Fluid resuscitation.
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics.
    • Surgical debridement of necrotic tissue.
  • Additional Measures:
    • Urinary and faecal diversion to prevent wound contamination.
    • Intensive monitoring for sepsis.
    • Wound review and vacuum-assisted dressing.
    • Skin grafting post-infection control.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a painless testicular mass. After orchidectomy, histopathological examination reveals the presence of Reinke's crystals within the tumor cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Leydig cell tumour

Sertoli cell tumor (Option A ruled out)

Hormonal involvement

It often involves androgens, estrogens, and corticosteroids.

Hormonally silent.

Conditions associated with
  • Klinefelter syndrome.
  • Cryptorchidism.
  • Renal cell carcinoma.
  • Carney complex.
  • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis.

Malignancy

10% (in adults)

10%

Gross
  • Circumscribed nodules, usually < 5 cm in diameter.
  • They have a distinctive golden brown, homogeneous appearance on cut surfaces.
  • Firm, small nodules with a homogeneous
  • grey-white to yellow cut surface.

Histology
  • The tumour cells resemble their normal counterparts.
  • They are large and have round or polygonal cell outlines, abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm, and a round central nucleus.
  • The cytoplasm frequently contains lipid droplets, vacuoles, or lipofuscin pigment and, most characteristically, rod-shaped Reinke crystalloids (25% of the tumors).
  • The tumour cells are arranged in distinctive trabeculae that tend to form cord-like structures and tubules.

 

Image

Grade

Description

Grade I

Pain develops after walking a certain distance (claudication distance). The pain subsides due to increased blood flow and collateral circulation.

Grade II

Pain persists even while continuing to walk, but the patient can still walk with effort.

Grade III

Patient must stop and rest to relieve the pain; walking becomes significantly impaired.

Grade IV

Patient experiences rest pain, and the pain persists even at rest, indicating severe arterial disease.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents with episodes of chest pain. Physical examination reveals a bisferiens pulse and a heaving apex. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM)

Feature

Characteristics

Pathophysiology
  • Autosomal dominant genetic disorder
  • Mutations in beta-myosin heavy-chain, troponin, and myosin-binding protein C
  • Inappropriate left ventricular hypertrophy

Key Physical Findings
  • Bisferiens (jerky arterial) pulse
  • Heaving apex
  • Mid-systolic murmur
  • Dynamic LVOT obstruction

Common Symptoms
  • Angina (chest pain)
  • Dyspnea
  • Syncope
  • MC cause of sudden death

Pathological Features
  • Misaligned myocardial fibers
  • Myocardial fibrosis
  • Rigid left ventricle
  • Impaired diastolic filling

Examination Findings

Clinical Finding

Description

Palpable Left Ventricular Hypertrophy

An enlarged left ventricle can be felt during physical examination, indicating hypertrophy.

Double Impulse at the Apex

A palpable fourth heart sound suggests forceful atrial contraction against a non-compliant ventricle.

Mid-Systolic Murmur at the Base

Turbulent blood flow through the obstructed left ventricular outflow tract produces a mid-systolic murmur.

Pansystolic Murmur at the Apex

Indicates mitral regurgitation caused by abnormal systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve.

Jerky Arterial Pulse

Characteristic of HOCM, contrasts with the slow-rising pulse seen in aortic stenosis.

Pulsus bisferiens

A double pulse noticed during systole in the peripheral pulse is called pulsus bisferiens. It is associated with severe aortic disease accompanied by aortic regurgitation and HOCM.

questions.text: What could be the possible diagnosis for a newborn exhibiting weak lower limb pulses and strong upper limb pulses?
questions.explanation:
Coarctation of the Aorta

Definition
  • Constrictions of the aorta of varying degrees at any point from the transverse arch to the iliac bifurcation.

Clinical presentation:
  • Differential cyanosis
  • Heart failure in severe cases
  • Weakness or pain/claudication (or both) in the legs after exercise
  • Radio-femoral delay: Disparity in pulsation and BP in the arms and legs
  • Systolic or continuous murmurs are heard over the left and right sides of the chest laterally and posteriorly due to collateral blood flow.

Investigation:
  • Chest x-ray:
  • The arrows indicate rib notching and the yellow line shows the site of coarctation
  • Enlarged left subclavian artery produces a prominent shadow in the left superior mediastinum.
  • Notching of the inferior border of the ribs from pressure erosion by enlarged collateral vessels (Common in late childhood after 1st decade of life)
  • Descending aorta has an area of post-stenotic dilation.
  • ECG, echocardiography, colour Doppler, CT, and MRI.

Treatment:
  • Infusion of prostaglandin E1 to reopen the ductus and reestablish adequate lower-extremity blood flow.
  • Surgical repair

questions.text: What condition is likely in a newborn presenting with dry, rough skin, a big tongue and rough hair?
questions.explanation:
Congenital Hypothyroidism

Clinical features
  • Usually birth weight & length is normal
  • Wide open anterior fontanelle
  • Delayed closure of anterior fontanelle
  • Prolonged physiological jaundice- Early sign (it is due to delayed maturation of glucuronide conjugation)
  • Myxedematous facies: Large, protruded tongue (Macroglossia)
  • Cold intolerance
  • Hypotonia
  • Rough skin and Rough hair
  • Constipation
  • Abdominal distension
  • Umbilical hernia
  • In Untreated Cases:
    • Delayed development
    • Intellectual disability
    • Delayed dentition
    • Short stature
    • Delayed puberty
    • Delayed bone maturation

X-ray findings in congenital hypothyroidism:
  • Absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphysis at birth
  • Punctate epiphyseal dysgenesis
  • Deformity or breaking of the 12th thoracic or 1st or 2nd lumbar vertebrae
  • X-ray image of skull- large fontanelle and wide sutures

Screening:
  • Universal newborn screening for congenital hypothyroidism
  • At birth, with umbilical cord blood
  • Heel prick: dried blood spots, sample collected beyond 48 hrs or 48-72hrs
  • Should not be done in first 1-2 days, to avoid TSH surge
  • Most sensitive approach- check for T4 and TSH both

ASH's first strategy:

  • Initial TSH screening using dried blood spot
  • If TSH>20mIU/L, recheck
  • Obtain a venous blood sample to check T4 and TSH levels if TSH remains elevated.

Treatment
  • Oral levothyroxine (early morning with empty stomach for older children; and for newborns, it is to be given at a fixed time).
  • The dose is higher in the earlier age group and as the babies grow the dose reduces.
  • Newborn- 10-15mg/kg/day
  • Children- 2-4mg/kg/day

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not a potential cause for the radiological finding shown below?
questions.explanation:
Whiteout hemithorax/Opacified hemithorax

Blackout hemithorax/Hyperlucent hemithorax

  • This refers to when there is complete opacification of an entire hemithorax.
  • Clinical information and other radiological findings are important to make a definite diagnosis.
  • This refers to an entire hyperlucent hemithorax.
  • It results from various congenital and acquired conditions of the pulmonary parenchyma, airway, pulmonary vasculature, pleural space, and chest wall.

Differential diagnoses

Differential diagnoses

  • Atelectasis of the entire lung
  • Large pleural effusion (Option C)
  • Pneumonia of the entire lung
  • Postpneumonectomy appearance
  • Large pulmonary, pleural, or chest wall mass in diseases like Ewing sarcoma, mesothelioma
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia or agenesis
  • Consolidation (Option A)
  • Collapse (Option B)
  • Radiologic technique errors
  • Emphysema (bullous emphysema)
  • Asymmetric chest wall soft tissue due to conditions like:
    • Poland syndrome
    • Unilateral mastectomy
    • Some professions like butchers, carpenters, etc
  • Atrophy of trapezius muscle after radical neck dissection
  • Extrapulmonary air collection in pneumothorax and subcutaneous emphysema
  • Contralateral large pleural effusion (Pseudo hyperlucent appearance of opposite lung)
  • Bronchial obstruction
    • Foreign body in children
    • Bronchial atresia
    • Endobronchial tumor
    • Broncholith
  • Bronchiolitis obliterans in Swyer-James syndrome
  • Congenital lobar hyperinflation
  • Conditions affecting pulmonary vessels:
    • Pulmonary agenesis or hypoplasia
    • Proximal interruption of pulmonary artery
    • Massive central pulmonary embolism (PE) leading to oligemia

questions.text: Which of the following is the type of joint between epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone?
questions.explanation:
Primary Cartilaginous Joints (Synchondrosis)

Secondary Cartilaginous Joints (Symphysis) (Option A)
  • Immobile
  • Occur where ossification centres remain separated by hyaline cartilage.
  • Found in bones that form from more than one ossification centre.
  • Hyaline cartilage here can ossify with age, leading to fusion when growth is completed.
  • Temporary and mainly for growth.
  • Mostly associated with growth plates. The joint between the first rib and the manubrium is a permanent synchondrosis.

 
  • Slightly mobile
  • Defined by a pad or disc of fibrocartilage between articulating bones, e.g., intervertebral discs.
  • Built to handle a variety of stresses (compression, tension, etc.).
  • Permanent and provide limited movement.
  • Found along the midline (e.g., pubic symphysis, intervertebral joints). Strong ligaments reinforce the joints and are key to stability and movement.
  • Symphyses are built for durability and movement, but they also allow growth in areas like the intervertebral discs.
